title: Mavrud
text:
Mavrud (, from <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a>, μαυρό "(mavró)", "<a href="black">black</a>") is a red <a href="wine">wine</a> <a href="grape">grape</a> that is used as both a blending grape and for <a href="varietal">varietal</a> wines, indigenous to the Balkan region. It's growing in some regions in <a href="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="Thrace">Thrace</a> region in <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, some regions in Greece and in Romania.
The grape has been described as a characterful, low-<a href="yield%20%28wine%29">yielding</a>, small-berried and late-ripening grape capable of producing <a href="tannins%20in%20grape">tannic</a>, spicy wine with a potential for <a href="Aging%20of%20wine">ageing</a>.
History.
Regarded as one of the most highly esteemed local wines, Mavrud vineyards are mainly found around <a href="Asenovgrad">Asenovgrad</a> and <a href="Perushtitsa">Perushtitsa</a>, as well as more rarely near <a href="Pazardzhik">Pazardzhik</a>, <a href="Stara%20Zagora">Stara Zagora</a> and <a href="Chirpan">Chirpan</a>.
There is speculation amongst grape growers that Mavrud may be an ancient clone of Mourvedre, imported into Bulgaria by the Romans.
Legend.
A legend that the <a href="oenophiles">oenophiles</a> of the Mavrud wine like to repeat in order to explain the restoration of this locality as wine-growing country was that during the reign of <a href="List%20of%20Bulgarian%20monarchs">Khan</a> <a href="Krum%20of%20Bulgaria">Krum of Bulgaria</a>, all <a href="vineyard">vineyard</a>s were ordered destroyed. Later, a lion escaped from its cage and terrorized the city. However, a fearless young man named Mavrud (now the name of a wine grape) confronted and slew the lion. The king summoned Mavrud's mother to learn the source of such courage. She said she had secretly saved a vine, made wine, and that this was the source of Mavrud's bravery. Khan Krum ordered the vineyards replanted.
In the original Bulgarian version the legend says it was a monster called the "lamyata" (ламята) which was vanquished, according to one book on wine.
